text.1:
Allah explains that this highly valuable Al-Qur'an was revealed from the side of Allah, the All-Mighty, the All-Wise. The attributes of Allah, the All-Mighty and the All-Wise, are mentioned in this verse so that it is clear to those who hear or read it that the Al-Qur'an contains true guidance. The values of its truth cannot be refuted or denied by anyone, and the values of wisdom within it cannot be doubted.

Evidence of the truth that the Al-Qur'an was revealed from Allah and contains true guidance is also explained in other verses.

Allah says:

"And indeed, this (the Qur'an) is a revelation from the Lord of the worlds. The Trustworthy Spirit (Jibril) has brought it down upon your heart, [O Muhammad] - that you may be of the warners - In a clear Arabic language." (ash-Shu'ara'/26: 192-195)

And His saying:

"Indeed, those who disbelieve in the message after it has come to them (will be punished), and indeed, it is a mighty Book. Falsehood cannot approach it from before it or from behind it; (it is) a revelation from a Wise, Praiseworthy (Lord)." (Fushshilat/41: 41-42)
text.2: Allah explains that He sent down to His Messenger the Book, Al-Qur'an, carrying truth and justice. The meaning of "carrying truth" in this verse is to bring the command to all mankind that they should worship only Allah, the One and Only. Then Allah explains that the correct way to worship is only to worship Allah alone, purifying obedience to Him, free from the influence of shirk and riya. The truth contained in the Al-Qur'an is in accordance with the truth contained in the books revealed to previous messengers. Thus, all worship directed to other than Allah or worship that is not directly directed to Him is incorrect worship.
text.3:
Allah then commanded His Messenger to remind his people that the sacred religion is the religion of Allah. The meaning of religion in this verse is worship and obedience. Therefore, worship and obedience should be directed to Allah alone, free from shirk and riya (showing off).

Idolaters believed that Allah is a Being beyond the reach of human senses. Therefore, it is impossible for humans to directly worship Him. If humans want to worship Him, according to them, they should use intermediaries entrusted with the task of conveying their worship to Allah. These intermediaries are angels and jinn, who sometimes resemble human form. They are considered gods. As for the carved statues placed in houses of worship, they are statues depicting gods, but not the real God. However, in general, ignorance causes them to no longer distinguish between statues and God, so they worship the statues as they worship Allah, like people who worship animals. They no longer distinguish between worshiping animals and worshiping the Creator of animals.

The Arabs of Jahiliyyah (the Age of Ignorance) depicted statues in various forms, some depicting stars, angels, prophets, and righteous people who had passed away. They worshiped these statues as symbols for each of those deities.

Such was the belief of the polytheists in the past and leading up to the sending of Muhammad saw as a messenger. Then the Messenger of Allah came with the command to destroy their objects of worship and eradicate the false beliefs from their minds, and replace them with teachings that guide the mind to embrace the religion of tawhid (monotheism).

Allah says:

And We certainly sent into every nation a messenger, [saying], "Worship Allah and avoid taghut." (an-Nahl/16: 36)

And His saying:

And We did not send any messenger before you (Muhammad) except that We revealed to him that, "There is no deity except Me, so worship Me." (al-Anbiya'/21: 25)

As a broader explanation of the Quraysh's recognition of the existence of Allah, Qatadah narrated that when the polytheists of Mecca were asked who their Lord was, who created them, and who created the heavens and the earth and sent down rain from the sky, they would answer, "Allah." Then when they were asked why they worshiped idols, they would answer, "So that the idols may bring them closer to Allah as close as possible and the idols may intercede for them when they need help from Allah."

Then, regarding the similar attitude of the polytheists, Allah says:

Then why did those deities they took besides Allah as means of nearness [to Him] not help them? Rather, they had vanished from them. (al-Ahqaf/46: 28)

Allah threatens their attitudes and actions and reveals to them the consequences they will feel. Allah will decide what they dispute on the Day of Reckoning. On that day, the truth of the religion of tawhid will no longer be able to be concealed, and the falsehood of idol worship will be clearly visible. Each of its adherents will receive a fitting reward. Those who remain steadfast to the religion of tawhid will have a return place full of pleasure. While those who are always wallowing in the valley of shirk will have a return place full of suffering.

In the final part of this verse, Allah emphasizes that He will not guide those who deny the truth and reject the religion of tawhid because of their irreparable error. The various ways they take to associate partners with Allah with other gods, such as worshiping idols, or assuming that Allah has a son, and so on. All of that is nothing but their assumptions that are far from the truth and drag them into the valley of error.
text.4:
Allah explains in more detail the actions that caused them to fall into error. Allah states that if He had desired to take a son, He would not have taken a son as they said. Of course, Allah is able to choose a son according to His will, and the one chosen would certainly be a male child. However, why do the disbelievers of Mecca say that Allah has daughters, when they themselves are reluctant to have daughters?

Allah says:

"Or has He daughters while you have sons?" (ath-Thur/52: 39)

And His saying:

"Is it for you the males and for Him the females? That is then, an unjust division." (an-Najm/53: 21-22)

The assumption that Allah has a child in any form is considered associating partners with Allah with other gods. This means dividing the power of God. In any case, the child would certainly inherit power from the father, and if that power is divided, then the omnipotence of Allah is lost. This cannot happen because Allah, who created the heavens and the earth and its contents, certainly has unlimited power, so His power cannot be divided.

That is why Allah emphasizes that He is Exalted above the attributes put forward by the polytheists. On the contrary, Allah emphasizes that He is One, neither begetting nor being begotten. He does not need anything, but He is the All-Prevailing. He is able to subdue whatever is in the heavens and on earth and all its contents, and force it to submit under His power and obey according to His will.
text.5:
Allah explains that He created the heavens and the earth with a true purpose. He adorned the sky with the sun and the moon. Each has its own orbit according to the provisions that Allah has established. Because of the earth's rotation on its axis, it seems as if the sun revolves in the sky from East to West, so that the alternation of day and night occurs. When the sun appears on the eastern horizon, day comes, and when the sun sets on the western horizon, night comes. This is what happens every day. This event occurs solely because of Allah's will, which He established when He created the universe.

Allah covering the night over the day is an expression of a parable where the day, marked by the brightness of sunlight, is likened to an open space, while the night, marked by the absence of sunlight, is likened to a curtain covering the open space. So, when it is said that the night covers the day, the meaning is that the brightness of sunlight is covered by the dark curtain of night. Allah covering the day over the night is the opposite of the parable mentioned. The day is likened to bright light, while the night is likened to dark places. When the day begins, the bright sunlight covers the darkness of the night, until the darkness of the night is replaced by bright light. This view is a daily view according to the observation of ordinary people.

However, if a person wants to think more carefully, he will be able to understand that the length of day and night is not the same. For places around the equator, the length of day and night is always about the same, around 12 hours. However, for places north of the equator, when the sun revolves in the north, the daytime for those areas becomes longer. The increase in daytime is directly proportional to the position of the place on earth and the position of the sun. So that in some places in the Arctic region, when the sun is in the northernmost part of the sky, those areas will experience continuous daylight.

It can be said that the further a place is from the equator and the further the position of the sun is from the celestial equator, the longer the daytime will be, until in certain areas there is continuous daylight. So, from the closest to the furthest from the equator, there is a part of the night that is covered by the day, which is getting longer. Until at one point, the day completely covers the night. This means that the day consumes the entire orbit of the sun. In other words, the day completely covers the night.

After that, Allah explains that He has subjected the sun and the moon. This means that the movement of the sun and the moon is in accordance with the provisions that Allah has arranged at the time of creation. If what is meant is the apparent daily movement of the sun, then from the time the sun culminates to the next culmination, it takes approximately 24 hours. But if what is meant is the annual revolution, namely the apparent revolution of the sun among the stars, it takes one year. Meanwhile, for the revolution of the moon from *ijtima'* to the next *ijtima'*, it takes one month. These time provisions of one month are according to the calculation of the calendar based on the revolution of the moon.

These time provisions of the revolution are only general provisions. To get more accurate figures, it requires a more careful and in-depth discussion. But what can be understood is that the sun and the moon revolve according to a certain revolution time; it can even be said that they revolve according to almost certain provisions. That is why Allah emphasizes that each celestial body revolves according to the time determined according to its respective revolution. Therefore, when the time comes, the sun and the moon will lose their balance, increasingly deviating from the provisions of their revolution. A similar thing will happen on the Day of Judgment, which is the day when the heavens and the earth and their contents are destroyed.

Allah says:

(Remember) the Day when We will roll up the heavens like a scroll of writings. (al-Anbiya'/21: 104)

At the end of the verse, Allah commands His servants to ask for forgiveness from Him by hurrying to worship and purify obedience to Him. Allah also reminds them that He is All-Powerful and His provisions cannot be disputed. Allah is the Most Forgiving for His servants who are aware and like to be guided to the right path.
text.6:
Allah shows the signs of His power that exist in the creation of humankind. Allah explains that He created humankind initially as a single person. Allah created humans with diverse colors and languages from the self of Adam. Then Allah created his partner, Hawa (Eve).

Allah also explains that He also created eight livestock animals in pairs. A pair of goats, a pair of sheep, a pair of camels, and a pair of cows.

Allah further explains about the creation of humankind. Humans are created through a process of events. The first process of creation is as a nutfah (drop of fluid), after that through a process like a clot of blood, then as a fetus. At the moment of becoming a perfect fetus, Allah creates the spirit within it, so it becomes a living being. The signs of its life can be known from its heartbeat by placing the ear to the mother's stomach. Regarding the process of human creation in the mother's womb, the Prophet Muhammad said:

"Verily, the creation of one of you occurs in his mother's womb for forty days as a sperm-drop, then he is a clot ('alaqah) for a similar period (40 days), then he is a lump of flesh ("Mudhgah") for a similar period (40 days). Then the angel is sent (by Allah), and he breathes the spirit into him, and Allah commands to decree four matters: his provision, his lifespan, his deeds, and whether he will be wretched or blessed." (Narrated by Muslim from Ibn Mas'ud)

In addition, Allah explains that when a baby is in the womb, it is in three darknesses, namely in the inner part of the membrane that covers the baby in the womb so that the baby is protected from the effects of decay. According to the eye, at a glance, the membrane seems to be only one layer, but when examined carefully, the membrane has three layers.

Scientists explain that the three layers of membranes that can secure the fetus while in the womb are:

1.  The amnion membrane layer containing fluid so that the fetus is in a swimming state. This condition protects the fetus if there is an external impact. In addition, this swimming position gives the fetus the opportunity to position itself when it is about to be born.

2.  The chorion membrane layer.

3.  The decidua membrane layer.

Some researchers connect the three layers of darkness in the verse above with the amniotic membrane layer surrounding the uterus, the uterine wall itself, and the abdominal wall in the stomach area.

Allah emphasizes that the One who does that is Allah, the Creator of humankind and the One who controls the heavens and the earth and its contents. Therefore, He is the One who deserves to be worshiped. There is no God worthy of worship except Him, the One and only, and has no partners.

At the end of the verse, Allah asks the polytheists a question that contains mockery towards them, why they can be turned away from worshiping only Allah, to become worshipers of idols, even though they have the ability to read the signs of Allah's oneness and power that exist in the universe and exist within themselves.
text.7:
Allah explains that if the polytheists continue to deny His Oneness, even though there is sufficient evidence for it, it will not harm Allah in the slightest. He does not need anything from any of His creation.

Allah says:

"And Moses said, "If you and those on earth, all of you, should disbelieve, indeed, Allah is Free of need and Praiseworthy." (Ibrahim/14: 8)

In a Hadith Qudsi, it is explained:

"O My servants, if the first of you and the last of you, mankind and jinn, were all to gather together in the heart of the most wicked man among you, that would not diminish My dominion in the least." (Narrated by Muslim from Abu Dharr al-Gifari)

Allah explains that He does not approve of disbelief for His servants. Disbelief is fundamentally contrary to the human soul. The human soul and all of Allah's creation are created according to their natural disposition (fitrah), which should be submissive to the decrees of their Creator. However, if they are grateful for Allah's blessings, then He certainly likes it, because such a state is indeed in accordance with their natural disposition and in accordance with Sunnatullah (Allah's way).

Allah says:

"If you are grateful, I will surely increase you [in favor]; but if you deny, indeed, My punishment is severe." (Ibrahim/14: 7)

Then Allah explains that each person, on the Day of Judgment, will be held accountable for their deeds when they lived in the world. Every sinner is responsible for his sins. He will not bear the sins of others. After that, each person will be driven to face his Lord to receive an explanation of the record of his deeds during his life in the world. Not a single good or bad deed will be left out. At that time, the deeds of each person will receive a fitting reward. If his record is full of good deeds, then he will get a place full of pleasure. But if his records are full of bad deeds, then he will get a place full of suffering. As Allah says:

"And that there is not for man except that [good] for which he strives. And that his effort is going to be seen - Then he will be recompensed for it with the fullest recompense." (an-Najm/53: 39-41)

It should be remembered that a person who commits an evil deed, and then another person follows him, then he will receive an additional sin from the evil deed committed by the person who imitates him. In connection with this, the Messenger of Allah once said the following:

"Whoever introduces a good practice in Islam, he will have its reward and the reward of whoever acts upon it until the Day of Resurrection without diminishing anything from their rewards. And whoever introduces an evil practice in Islam, he will bear its sin and the sin of whoever acts upon it until the Day of Resurrection without diminishing anything from their sins." (Narrated by Muslim and an-Nasa'i from Abu Dharr)

At the end of this verse, Allah explains that He is All-Knowing of what is stored in the hearts of His servants. Thus, it is impossible for any deed to escape Allah's knowledge, whether it is a deed that can be witnessed by others or a deed that is only known by the perpetrator himself.
text.8:
Allah explains the attitude of those who deny Allah's blessings. When they are afflicted with harm, whether in the form of illness or suffering that befalls their lives, they seek help from Allah, so that their illness or suffering is eliminated. They also declare themselves repentant, asking forgiveness for their bad deeds in the past. However, when they receive blessings, where their illness and suffering have disappeared, they forget the words they pledged when they prayed. Then they fabricate other gods as partners with Allah. They not only mislead themselves, but also mislead others, hindering those who declare themselves as people of monotheistic religion (tauhid).

At the end of the verse, Allah commands His Messenger to say to those who deny Allah's blessings, "Indulge yourself in fulfilling your desires while living in this world, enjoy its pleasures which are not long-lasting, until death snatches your soul. At that time, you will regret your actions. On the Day of Reckoning, you will know for certain that you will be inhabitants of Hell, which is full of torment."
text.9:
Then Allah commanded His Messenger to ask the disbelievers of Mecca whether they were more fortunate than those who worshiped during the night, prostrating and standing with great devotion. In performing that worship, fear of Allah's torment in the Hereafter arose in their hearts, and hope for Allah's mercy radiated forth.

Allah gave the same command to His Messenger to ask them whether those who know are equal to those who do not know. What is meant by those who know are those who know the reward they will receive for their good deeds, and the punishment they will receive if they commit disobedience. While those who do not know are those who do not know this at all, because they have no hope whatsoever of receiving reward for their good deeds, and do not expect at all to receive punishment for their bad deeds.

At the end of the verse, Allah states that only those with understanding can take a lesson. The lesson can be from their life experiences or from the signs of Allah's greatness found in the heavens and the earth and their contents, as well as those found within themselves, or examples from the stories of past nations.
text.10:
Allah commands His Messenger to call upon all of Allah's servants and advise them to remain pious to Allah, obeying all His commands and avoiding all His prohibitions. Mankind is commanded to be pious because those who do good in this world will also receive good. They will be granted health, prosperity, and success in carrying out their life's tasks. All of this can be achieved because they always have good morals and noble character, as is usually done by those who are pious. In addition, they will also receive good in the hereafter, namely, obtaining a place full of pleasure and obtaining Allah's pleasure.

Allah also commands the Muslims to prepare themselves to migrate to Medina, and commands them to be patient because they are separated from their homeland, relatives, and friends. This command is given with the explanation that if the Muslims' freedom to carry out Allah's commands in Mecca is disturbed, then they should migrate to another country that allows them to have peace in carrying out Allah's commands.

This command is depicted in Allah's concise words, "And the earth of Allah is spacious."

Allah says:

"Was not the earth of Allah spacious [enough] for you to emigrate therein?" (an-Nisa'/4: 97)

At the end of the verse, Allah explains that only those who are patient will receive unlimited rewards, as felt by the previous ummah.
text.11: In this verse, Allah commands His Messenger to say to the polytheists of Mecca that he is commanded to worship Allah and obey His commands by purifying obedience to Him in carrying out religious affairs. From this explanation, it can be understood that deities other than Allah must be eradicated to their roots. Likewise, regarding religious matters, the guideline is the command that comes from Allah, and it should not be based on people's opinions.
text.12:
The Messenger of Allah was also commanded to be the first to submit to Allah. Thus, the Messenger of Allah became a role model whose every action should be emulated and what he forbade should be avoided. He became a role model in purifying *tauhid* (monotheism), purifying worship, and cleansing oneself from the behavior and actions of the polytheists of Mecca.

The submission meant in this verse is to submit to all of Allah's provisions, whether related to the commands of *syara'* (Islamic law) or to submit and obey Allah's provisions related to the *sunnah kauniyah* (natural laws).
text.13: In this verse, the Messenger of Allah is also commanded to fear violating Allah's prohibitions, such as not being sincere in carrying out His commands and in His Oneness (Tawhid). If he fears violating His prohibitions, it means fearing the terrible torment that will be inflicted on the Day of Reckoning. On that day, all of humanity's deeds, good or bad, will be examined and given a fitting reward.
text.14: After that, Allah commanded His Messenger to say to his people that he worships only Allah and that he purifies obedience for Him alone in carrying out religious affairs. From this verse, it can be understood that in carrying out religious affairs, there must be a clear dividing line, and there should be no mixing between monotheism (Tawhid) and polytheism (Shirk). Between what is commanded by religion and what is not. In matters of faith (Aqidah) and worship (Ibadah), there is no compromise, while in matters of the world and benefit (maslahat), it can be solved with ijtihad, as long as the principle does not contradict religious teachings.
text.15:
In this verse, Allah commands His Messenger to say to the polytheists of Mecca, and to let them worship those idols according to their desires. They have been given repeated warnings and guidance many times. However, they still persist in their stance, following in the footsteps of their ancestors based only on assumptions far from the truth.

As a final affirmation, the Messenger of Allah is commanded to declare to them that the losers are those who harm themselves. This means that if they are later punished with a terrible torment, that suffering is solely due to their own actions. The loss and suffering will not only befall them, but also their families who share their views.

At the end of this verse, Allah emphasizes that such loss and suffering is a manifest loss and suffering, because there is no loss and suffering more terrible than the loss they will suffer on the Day of Judgment.
text.16:
In this verse, Allah explains the suffering they will experience. They will be placed in the midst of the layers of hellfire. At the top, there are layers of fire, and below as well. They are at the peak of suffering, because they are surrounded by hellfire.

Allah says:

"On the Day when the torment shall cover them from above them and from under their feet, and it will be said (to them), "Taste what you used to do!" (al-'Ankabut/29: 55)

And His saying:

"For them there will be a bed of Hellfire, and over them coverings (of Hellfire)." (al-A.'raf/7: 41)

These terrible punishments are presented by Allah only to frighten His servants, so that they become aware and repent and return to the straight path, the path shown by the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him), and are eager to seek forgiveness from Allah for the sins they have committed.

At the end of the verse, Allah commands His Messenger to call upon His servants to be pious, to willingly obey His commands, and to avoid His prohibitions. This call demonstrates Allah's compassion towards His servants and His invaluable wisdom.
text.17:
This verse explains about those who always guard themselves and avoid worshipping *thagut*, idols, and are steadfast in facing the temptations of Satan, devoting themselves and worshipping Allah alone, not worshipping anything besides Him. They will receive good news from the messengers that they will be spared from the torment of the grave after death, and the misery of the Gathering Place (*Padang Mahsyar*). They will receive eternal bliss in Paradise. Therefore, the Prophet Muhammad is commanded to give good news to his people who always worship Allah, and always listen to the true word, and do what is best of all those true words. They will also obtain what is obtained by the pious servants of Allah. They are those who always follow the guidance of Allah and always use sound reason.

Narrated by Ibn Abi Hatim from Zaid bin Aslam that this verse was revealed in connection with three companions of the Messenger of Allah, namely Zaid bin 'Amr, Abu Dharr al-Ghifari, and Salman al-Farisi. These three were people who had uttered the phrase "*La ilaha illallah*" during the Arab Jahiliyyah (era of ignorance).

text.19: This verse explains the opposite of the characteristics of the people mentioned in the previous verse, namely those who claim to be capable of carrying out everything and overcoming all kinds of difficulties. Allah rebukes them by saying, "Are you the ones who control all human affairs, regulate and control their circumstances? Can you change My decree by nullifying the punishment that I have decreed for those who constantly defile their souls by committing all kinds of sins and doing things that I have forbidden?" Allah affirms that they can never erase or change any of His decrees in the slightest, because the determination of all things is in His hand.
text.20: In this verse, the mention of deeds pleasing to Allah is repeated, namely all acts of piety, obligatory acts, and recommended (sunnah) acts. Those who perform these deeds will later be placed in chambers of Paradise where everything they desire is found, adorned with beautiful gardens through which rivers flow. That is Allah's promise to every believer who is pious. That promise is a true promise, which will not be broken in the slightest, because Allah will not break His promise.
text.21:
In this verse, Allah commands mankind to contemplate one of the processes occurring in nature, namely the process of rainfall and the growth of plants on the earth's surface. If observed, it seems as if this event is a cycle that begins at a point in a circle, starting from the existence of something, then developing into something large, then aging, then dying or ceasing to exist, then a new event begins again, and so on until a time determined by Allah, which is the time when this natural event ends.

According to scientific studies, the distribution and dynamics of water in the soil are described in this verse. In addition to becoming runoff that flows directly on the soil surface, some of the water that falls from the sky, whether as rainwater or melting snow, will recharge (infiltrate) into the soil and spread within the soil's porosity (pores). Water will be held by the soil pores with a force inversely proportional to the size of the soil pores.

In soil pores with a large size, water can be pulled by gravity and can flow (percolate) to lower layers of soil or rock or flow laterally along the slope. Shallow groundwater that flows along the slope will reappear as springs. Water that flows to a lower layer will then fill the groundwater aquifer, which is a layer of soil or rock composed of coarse grains, mainly sand. If this aquifer emerges to the surface, for example, at a slope break, then springs will also be found at the point of emergence.

Smaller pores, known as capillary pores, will retain water within them as soil moisture. The water contained in these capillary pores will not be released except by a tension greater than the force of gravity, generally by evaporation, or in deeper layers by the suction force of plant roots. This soil moisture is then used by plants for metabolism and then evaporates from the stomata of leaves and other chlorophyll-containing parts of the plant. The evaporation of soil water in this way is known as transpiration. Soil with sufficient moisture will be characterized by plants covering it having green leaves. If the moisture decreases, the leaves will gradually turn yellow and then dry out. The dried leaves will fall off to reduce the evaporation process.

Water that evaporates from the heat of the sun then becomes clumpy clouds, driven back by the wind to a place where it rains. This process becomes food for thought for those who want to use their minds. Surely there is an Almighty Being who regulates all of this, so that everything happens in an orderly and neat manner. It is impossible for humans to do it. The One who does all of that is certainly the Being who has the right to be worshiped and obeyed in all His commands.
text.22:
This verse affirms that those whose hearts Allah has opened to accept Islam are not the same as those whose hearts are misguided, causing them to deny the truth. The former have seen Allah's power and greatness in the beauty and wonders of this universe, and their hearts have opened to receive the radiant light of the Divine. Conversely, those whose hearts are misguided do not see the signs of Allah's power and greatness in the events of this universe; they assume that these events are merely natural processes, without any regulator. They feel capable of changing or improving these processes. This is due to their ignorance and narrow-mindedness, which keeps their hearts closed, preventing the radiant light of the Divine from entering. These two types of people are certainly not the same. In another verse, Allah affirms the dissimilarity between these two types of people. Allah says:

"Is one who was dead and We gave him life and made for him light by which to walk among the people like one who is in darkness, never to emerge therefrom?" (al-An'am/6: 122)

Ibn 'Abbas narrated, "Among those whose breasts Allah had expanded to [accept] Islam was Abu Bakr r.a." Ibn Mardawaih narrated from Ibn Mas'ud, he said:

"The Messenger of Allah (saw) recited this verse, and we asked, 'O Prophet of Allah, how is an open heart?' He replied, 'When light illuminates the heart, it becomes open and spacious.' We asked, 'What is the sign of that, O Messenger of Allah?' He replied, 'Turning towards the life of the eternal abode, turning away from the life of deception, and preparing for death before it comes.'" (Narrated by Ibn Mardawaih)

At-Tirmidhi narrated from Ibn 'Umar, he said:

"That someone said, 'O Messenger of Allah, which of the believers is the best?' The Messenger of Allah replied, 'Those who remember death the most and prepare for it the most, and when light shines in their hearts, the heart opens and becomes spacious.' The companions asked, 'What is the sign of that, O Prophet of Allah?' The Prophet replied, 'Turning towards the eternal abode, turning away from the land of deception, and preparing for death before it comes.'"

As for those whose hearts are hard and stony, they will experience great misfortune because of their stubborn refusal to remember Him. Their hearts should soften when the name of God is mentioned before them, but their faces turn dark and gloomy when they hear the name of Allah mentioned, and their hearts become even harder and stonier.

At-Tirmidhi narrated from Ibn 'Umar, he said: The Messenger of Allah (saw) said:

"Do not engage in excessive talk without mentioning Allah, for excessive talk without mentioning Allah hardens the heart. And indeed, the person furthest from Allah is the one with the hardest heart."

At the end of this verse, it is explained that those whose hearts are hard are those whose inner eyes are blind; they are truly in manifest error. Everyone can easily recognize their wickedness.
text.23:
Allah explains that He has sent down the best of speech, which is the noble Al-Qur'an, some of whose verses resemble each other, whether in explaining laws, truths, lessons, presenting arguments, wisdoms, and so on, just as some parts of water resemble some parts of air, some parts of a country resemble some parts of another country. Because there are stories repeated in several places, as are commands, prohibitions, and so on. The believers, when they hear the recitation of the Al-Qur'an, their skin shivers, and their hearts tremble with fear of Allah. This encourages their hearts to follow all of Allah's commands and stop His prohibitions. Their souls become alive, their enthusiasm increases to carry out righteous deeds and strive in His path.

With the Al-Qur'an, Allah guides His servants, guiding those He wills to the straight path and strengthening faith in their hearts. But those whose hearts are misguided, they are empty and void, they will not obtain any benefit from the Al-Qur'an.
text.24: In this verse, Allah affirms the difference in the state of those who receive guidance and those who do not. Those who are astray and do not receive guidance will be brought to Hellfire on the Day of Judgment. The fire of Hell will burn their faces, and their hands will not be able to cover their faces from the heat of the fire, because both their hands will be shackled. This is different from the believers. They are saved from the fire of Hell and do not need to avoid punishment like that inflicted upon the disbelievers. On that Day, the disbelievers will be reproached by the angels, who will say, "Taste the burning punishment of the Fire, because of the deeds you used to do when you were alive in the world."
text.25:
In this verse, Allah explains the punishment that was inflicted upon previous peoples who denied the messengers sent to them, just as the polytheists of Mecca did to the Messenger of Allah. This punishment was inflicted upon them after they had been repeatedly called to the path of truth by the messengers sent to them, but they did not heed the call.

Thus, they were afflicted with punishment in this world, and in the Hereafter they will receive a severe punishment. The punishment of this world is far lighter and easier to bear compared to the punishment of the Hereafter.

text.27:
In this verse, Allah explains that He has made various examples in the Qur'an, such as explaining the history of some previous peoples, reminding them of the disasters they experienced. These examples and parables are presented to them so that they may learn lessons from them, both related to worldly life and related to the afterlife. By taking guidance from the Qur'an, they can straighten out their misguided beliefs, improve their chaotic way of life, and transform it into a civilized life.

It is not difficult for them to understand the Qur'an because it was revealed in Arabic, their own language. There is nothing contradictory in it. Its contents are clear and firm, whether related to *aqidah* (creed), law, morals, and so on. If they are willing to believe and follow the guidance of the Qur'an, they will surely be able to protect themselves from disasters that may befall them, and they will certainly be obedient only to Allah.

text.29:
Allah makes a parable to explain the difference between shirk and tawhid. For this, Allah uses the example of two slaves. One slave is owned by several masters, who share ownership of him. While the other slave is owned by only one master, no one else owns him. At one point, the first slave receives orders from his masters with different commands, such as the first master ordering him to clean the yard of his house, the second master ordering him to hoe his garden, the third master ordering him to clean his house, and so on. These orders are given at the same time. Which master's order should the slave carry out? It is impossible for the slave to carry out each order from his masters at the same time. And so it continues, so that the slave is always confused in obeying the orders from each of his masters.

As for the second slave who is owned by only one master, he can carry out his master's orders well, he will not be confused in carrying out the order, and his master is also relieved because his slave can carry out his orders well. Are the conditions of the two slaves the same, and are the conditions of the masters of each slave the same?

Such is the case with people who adhere to tawhid and people who adhere to shirk. People who adhere to tawhid are never confused in carrying out the commands and prohibitions of their Lord, because the commands and prohibitions originate from the One and Only. A person who adheres to shirk is always in a state of confusion, which god's command should he follow. Conversely, a person who adheres to tawhid only worships the One God, while a person who adheres to shirk is always confused, which god is more worthy of worship than the other gods.

After explaining the error of shirk, Allah affirms that all praise is only for Him, not for others. Only He is worthy of worship, but most people do not want to know.
text.30:
Allah explains that all humans will return to God and on the Day of Judgment, people will argue and accuse each other. On the Day of Judgment, the polytheists will try to defend themselves, but the Prophet Muhammad (saw) will be able to reject their reasons, stating that the message had been conveyed to them, but they denied and rejected it. Therefore, they will ask for forgiveness from Allah, but their request will not be accepted, because on that day repentance will no longer be accepted.

Among the arguments between the polytheists and their objects of worship is mentioned in this verse. They will say to their leaders, "We followed you, but you misled us." The leaders will answer, "We were also deceived by the devils and our ancestors before us."

text.32:
This verse explains that there is no one more unjust than those who fabricate lies against Allah, by establishing other objects of worship, or saying that the angels are daughters of Allah. They also deny the truth of the Qur'an brought by the Prophet Muhammad, which calls to monotheism, enjoins good and forbids evil, and informs of the coming of the Day of Resurrection and Recompense. They deny precisely when the truth comes to them, as if they close their minds and senses to conduct investigations or distinguish between what is right and what is wrong, as is done by conscious and reasonable people.

All of this arises from arrogance and pride. Therefore, Allah conveys a severe threat in the form of a question, "Is there not in Hell an abode for the disbelievers?" The method of conveying threats in the form of questions is often found in the Qur'an, because its benefit is very great for those who are seeking the truth. The question causes surprise or at least attention for those who are negligent and heedless. In accordance with *sunnatullah* (Allah's law), after conveying a threat to the disbelievers, Allah then gives good news and praise to the Prophet Muhammad and his companions and followers who are always devoted to Him.
text.33: As for the one who brought the truth, namely Muhammad, peace be upon him, and those who affirmed it, namely his companions and followers until the Day of Judgment. They are always mindful of Allah, do not worship idols and statues, always fulfill the obligations of the Sharia, and carry out *amar ma'ruf nahi mungkar* while hoping for reward and avoiding His punishment. They are the ones meant by the group of people who are righteous.
text.34: They will obtain rewards and honor in the sight of Allah, whom they always obey and worship. In Paradise, they will obtain whatever they desire in the sight of Allah. In several authentic hadith, it is explained that in Paradise they will encounter various blessings that have never been seen by the eye, heard by the ear, or imagined in the heart. That is the reward for those who always prioritize good deeds, with a sincere heart in secret or in the open, who always guard their actions and words, whether concerning matters heavy or light, great or small. They face all of that with a full sense of responsibility.
text.35: All blessings, rewards, and gifts are bestowed by Allah upon them. Allah also forgives the worst deeds they ever committed in the world. Allah does not repay their sins and mistakes with torment, but rather conceals their sins and evil deeds and rewards them with a reward better than what they have done. In this verse, the forgiveness of sins is prioritized over the giving of rewards, because a person whose sins are forgiven has already felt peace. Moreover, Allah's forgiveness is wider than the sins of His servants.
text.36:
In this verse, Allah explains some of the blessings bestowed upon Prophet Solomon, as an answer to his prayer. First: Allah granted Solomon the power to subdue the wind. With Allah's permission, the wind blew strongly or gently according to his will.

Allah says:

"And to Solomon (We subjected) the wind, blowing forcefully, proceeding by his command toward the land which We had blessed. And We are ever, of all things, Knowing." (al-Anbiya'/21: 81)

Second: Allah granted him the ability to subdue devils who were skilled in construction and diving, performing tasks according to Solomon's commands. If he ordered them to build a building such as palace meeting halls, defensive fortresses, or buildings to store Solomon's wealth and others, they could complete the task in a very short time. If Solomon ordered them to collect pearls and coral and other marine riches, the task could also be completed quickly.

Third: Allah granted him the power to subdue devils who defied his commands. Their hands and feet were bound in shackles, so that they would not be dangerous to others, and as punishment for their disobedience.

The power that Allah gave to Solomon to subdue the devils meant the power to move them to perform heavy tasks, namely the task of building buildings, and diving to extract marine wealth. However, there is no definite information about how Solomon shackled the devils. The most important attitude is that we accept the information contained in the Qur'an and to reveal its meaning, we submit it to science.

text.40: In this verse, Allah threatens us all in the form of a question, namely, who will receive a humiliating punishment, and who will continuously receive that punishment? This threat in the form of a question indicates to us that there are indeed people who receive a humiliating punishment, both in this world and the hereafter. Disbelievers and the disobedient can also receive that punishment continuously and eternally. Therefore, we need to be careful not to receive the threatened punishment by becoming obedient believers who always put their trust in Allah (tawakal).
text.41:
This verse explains that indeed Allah has sent down the Al-Qur'an to the Prophet Muhammad saw with the truth. He was then commanded to convey the teachings of Allah's religion to all mankind by giving glad tidings of the coming of Allah's mercy and giving warnings of the coming of Allah's punishment for those who deny it. The Al-Qur'an contains all the guidance needed by humans in regulating all aspects of their lives. With that, they become a happy people in this world and the hereafter because they take the straight path.

Whoever receives guidance to practice the contents of the Al-Qur'an, then the benefit of that guidance is for himself, because they will receive Allah's pleasure, be admitted into Paradise, and be saved from Hell. And whoever deviates from the straight path so that he goes astray, then indeed that only harms himself. He will fall into destruction and ruin because he will receive Allah's wrath and experience suffering in the fire of Hell. On the Day of Judgment, no one will be saved except those who truly bring a pure heart, in accordance with Allah's word:

(It is) the Day when there will not benefit [anyone] wealth or children, But only one who comes to Allah with a sound heart. (ash-Shu'ara'/26: 88-89)

Allah then explains that the Prophet Muhammad is not responsible for their deeds. His task is solely to convey the message as explained in His word:

You are only a warner, and Allah is Guardian over all things. (Hud/11: 12)

His word also:

So remind, for you are only a reminder. You are not over them a controller. (al-Gasyiyah/88: 21-22)
text.42:
In this verse, Allah explains one type of His perfect power and His awe-inspiring attributes. Namely, He is the One who takes possession of the souls of humans when their appointed time arrives by severing the connection between the soul and the body, and He holds the soul of that person only outwardly so that it cannot control the body, but the connection between them still remains. Allah withholds the soul of the one whose death He has decreed by not returning the soul, and releases the other soul by returning the soul to its body, so that it can wake up from its sleep until the appointed time. The soul of the deceased is withheld by Allah so that it cannot return to its body, and the one who has not died is only sleeping, his soul is released so that it can return to his body again.

It is narrated from Ibn 'Abbas that in the human body there is a soul ( *nafs* ) and a spirit ( *ruh* ) whose relationship is like sunlight. The mind and soul can think and make choices, while the spirit is what causes it to live and move. Both are put to death when their appointed time arrives, and only the soul is put to death when it sleeps, while the spirit still remains.

Imam al-Bukhari and Muslim narrated a hadith from Abu Hurairah which reads:

The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said, "When one of you goes to sleep, let him blow into his garment on the inside, because he does not know what is left in it, then let him say, "O my Lord, in Your name I lay down my side, and in Your name I raise it. If You withhold my soul, then have mercy on it, and if You release it again, then protect it as You protect the righteous." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

Imam al-Bukhari, Ahmad, Abu Dawud, and Ibn Abi Shaybah narrated a hadith from Abu Qatadah which reads:

Indeed, the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said to his companions on the night (when sleeping) in the valley, "Indeed, Allah withholds your souls when He wills, and returns them when He wills."
text.43: In this verse, Allah refutes the polytheists' assumption that the idols they worship besides Allah can intercede for them on the Day of Judgment, and provide assistance to them in achieving their goals and hopes. Such a thing cannot be justified by anyone with a sound mind. Therefore, the Prophet Muhammad was instructed by Allah to rebuke those polytheists who held such assumptions with the statement, "Do you think that these idols can provide benefit even though they possess nothing and have no intellect?" Then Allah clarifies that indeed, the only one who can grant intercession is Allah.
text.44:
In this verse, Allah commands His Prophet to say that all intercession belongs solely to Allah. No one can give intercession except with Allah's permission, as mentioned in His saying:

"There is no one that can intercede with Him except with His permission." (al-Baqarah/2: 255)

And as in His saying:

"and they cannot intercede except for him with whom He is pleased." (al-Anbiya'/21: 28)

All intercession belongs only to Allah because He owns the kingdom of the heavens and the earth and all that is in them, including the idols worshipped by the polytheists. Therefore, worship only Allah, who possesses the perfect kingdom, whose power is unlimited. Then to Him you will all be returned on the Day of Resurrection. He is the One who will inflict a very painful punishment on the polytheists. There is no doubt that this verse contains a very severe threat. Then Allah also explains a very bad characteristic of those who deny His Oneness.
text.45:
In this verse, Allah explains that if only the name of Allah is mentioned, and there is no God worthy of worship in truth except Him, then the hearts of those who do not believe in the Hereafter become wild and angry. Their hearts are annoyed and hear the sentence of *tauhid* (Oneness of God). However, when the names of deities other than Allah are mentioned, suddenly they become happy and rejoice. 'Abdullah bin 'Abbas explained the meaning of this verse, "The hearts of four people who did not believe in the Day of Resurrection became hardened and wild, namely: Abu Jahal bin Hisyam, al-Walid bin 'Utbah, Shafwan, and Ubay bin Khalaf, as mentioned in His word:

And when you mention your Lord alone in the Qur'an, they turn back in aversion. (al-Isra'/17: 46)

In the *tafsir* (Quran commentary) *Ruh al-Ma'ani*, al-Alusi said, "We often encounter people in this day and age whose characteristics resemble those of the polytheists mentioned in this verse, namely, they like to ask for help from the dead, and are very happy to remember and reveal their exaggerated life stories, which go hand in hand with their desires. They greatly glorify those they idolize. Their hearts become annoyed if only the name of Allah is mentioned or it is said that only Allah is worthy of worship in truth, and only Allah may be asked for help."
text.46:
In this verse, Allah teaches His Prophet to utter the following words to strengthen faith and beseech for additional guidance and direction from Him: "O Allah, Creator of the heavens and the earth, Knower of the unseen and the seen, You decide all disputes between Your servants concerning what they always disputed. You are the One who will decide on the Day of Judgment who among us is right and who is wrong, who is guided and who is astray."

Through his hadith, the Messenger of Allah taught a prayer to be recited upon waking up for the night prayer:

"O Allah, Lord of Jibril, Mikail, and Israfil, Creator of the heavens and the earth, Knower of all that is unseen and seen. You decide between Your servants in matters in which they dispute. Guide me to the truth concerning what is disputed with Your permission. Indeed, You guide whom You will to the straight path." (Narrated by Muslim, Abu Dawud, and al-Baihaqi)
text.47: In this verse, Allah explains that if those unjust polytheists possessed all the wealth on earth and as much again, they would surely ransom themselves with that wealth from the evil and terrible torment that will be inflicted upon them on the Day of Resurrection. A similar threat has also been mentioned in Surah Ali 'Imran. The torment from Allah will become apparent to them, the existence and severity of which they had never considered. The polytheists consider something they do as good deeds, whereas in reality what they do is a form of evil.
text.48: It became clear to them when the books containing records of their deeds during their lives in the world were presented to them, all their evil deeds were recorded there. They were certain that those transgressions would be reckoned and accounted for one by one. As a result, they would receive a painful torment encompassing all directions, all of which was none other than because they had always mocked the teachings of the religion of Allah.
text.49: This verse explains the strange state of the polytheists. If they are afflicted by harmful dangers such as poverty and illness, they immediately seek protection and pray to Allah. But when the situation has changed, such as being cured of illness, receiving blessings, and having abundant sustenance, they forget the time of suffering and say that all of that is due to their own merits, skills, intelligence, and experience. That is their very strange attitude. When experiencing suffering, they run screaming, begging for help from Allah. After the situation changes to pleasure and enjoyment, they sever their relationship with their Creator and declare that all the improvement in their fate is due to their own cleverness and skill. They do not know that indeed the good and bad fortune that Allah gives them is a test to know who is grateful for Allah's blessings and who is ungrateful for them. For those who are grateful, other blessings will be added, while for those who deny them, a painful torment will be inflicted.
text.50: In this verse, Allah explains that such utterances have also been heard from communities before them, so such assumptions are not new. What they used to strive for was useless in warding off the coming of Allah's punishment because they always acted in a way that denied and mocked the arrival of Allah's messengers.
text.51: This verse explains that they were afflicted by the evil consequences of what they did. Allah hastened the coming of punishment upon them, like Qarun who was swallowed by the earth, the thunderbolt that struck the people of Lut, and the eternal disaster that will befall them in the Hereafter. The wrongdoers among them will be afflicted by the evil consequences of their efforts, including the polytheists who always opposed the Messenger of Allah (saw). They will certainly be afflicted with punishment as a result of their disbelief, like the punishment inflicted upon those who came before. Among the examples of this punishment is the famine that struck them for seven years, and their leaders being killed and captured during the Battle of Badr. They will also not be able to escape and flee from the punishment of Allah on the Day of Judgment.
text.52:
In this verse, Allah demonstrates evidence of His power, majesty, and wisdom. The polytheists do not know that it is Allah who expands provision for whom He wills and restricts it for whom He wills. It is an undeniable reality that people's circumstances differ regarding possessions and wealth; some are very rich, and some are very poor. This cannot be attributed solely to intelligence or skill. Sometimes, highly educated people live in deprivation, while those with little education live in abundance.

Indeed, in that event, there are signs of Allah's power for a people who believe. They know that all of this is regulated by Allah. There is no event in this life that is outside of His regulation.
text.53:
In this verse, Allah commands the Prophet Muhammad to convey to his people that Allah, the Most Forgiving, the Most Merciful, and whose mercy and compassion are vast towards His believing servants, will forgive all the sins they have committed, such as neglecting His commands or committing His prohibitions, if they sincerely repent from their mistakes. Many people assume that because their sins have accumulated, Allah will no longer forgive them. Thus, they become despairing of His forgiveness, mercy, and compassion. The world becomes dark in their eyes because they have ignored the teachings of their religion and always turned their backs on the guidance contained within it. Their hearts are filled with impurity and disobedience, and they can no longer see the path of truth and goodness to follow. They have been confused by despair, and there is no hope for them to return from the error and disobedience they have always committed. But Allah, even though His servant's sins are great, still loves and cares for them and forbids them from despairing of His mercy and compassion. He still regards them as His servants who deserve to receive His love if they realize their mistakes and ask for His forgiveness. Not only for believers, but for polytheists as well, the door to repentance is still open if they embrace Islam and believe in Allah and His Messenger.

Narrated by Imam al-Bukhari from Sa'id bin Jubair from Ibn 'Abbas that many of the polytheists who had committed many murders and often committed adultery came to the Prophet Muhammad. They said to him, "Indeed, what you call us to is good. Can you explain to us whether what we did before will be forgiven by Him?"

The Prophet replied by reciting Allah's words:

"And those who do not invoke with Allah another deity or kill the soul which Allah has forbidden [to be killed], except by right, and do not commit unlawful sexual activity. And whoever should do that will meet a penalty. Multiplied for him is the punishment on the Day of Resurrection, and he will abide therein humiliated - Except for those who repent, believe and do righteous work. For them Allah will replace their evil deeds with good. And ever is Allah Forgiving and Merciful." (al-Furqan/25: 68-70)

In a hadith of the Prophet saw, it is also explained:

Narrated from 'Amr bin 'Anbasah that an old man came to the Prophet saw, leaning on his staff, and said to him, "O Messenger of Allah, I have committed many mistakes and sins. Is it possible for those mistakes to be forgiven?" The Prophet saw replied, "Have you acknowledged that there is no god but Allah?" The old man replied, "Yes, indeed, I acknowledge that you are the Messenger of Allah." The Messenger of Allah saw affirmed, "Allah forgives all the mistakes and sins that you have committed." (Riwayat A.hmad)

These hadiths affirm that Allah forgives all sins, no matter how great and numerous, if a person truly repents with a sincere heart, vows not to return to committing mistakes, and will continue to do good deeds. A servant of Allah must not despair of His forgiveness, mercy, and compassion, because the door of His mercy is open wide for those who repent, as affirmed in His words:

"And whoever does a wrong or wrongs himself but then seeks forgiveness of Allah will find Allah Forgiving and Merciful." (an-Nisa'/4: 110)

After forbidding His servants from despairing of His mercy and compassion, Allah encourages His servants to immediately ask for forgiveness and repent to Him for all the mistakes and errors they have committed. Allah also affirms that He forgives all sins except the sin of shirk, as mentioned in His words:

"Indeed, Allah does not forgive association with Him, but He forgives what is less than that for whom He wills. And he who associates others with Allah has certainly fabricated a tremendous sin." (an-Nisa'/4: 48)

Indeed, Allah's mercy towards His servants is great and vast. A servant who has disobeyed by ignoring His commands, violating the laws He has established, and wallowing in sin and disobedience, is still called His servant and advised not to despair of His forgiveness and mercy.
text.54:
For those who accept this call by repenting to Allah and believing with all their hearts in the vastness of His mercy and forgiveness, Allah commands them to truly return to the straight path that He has laid out, surrender to Him, and seek refuge under His protection. With Allah, there are various kinds of gifts and blessings that will be bestowed upon them, if they have realized their mistakes and returned to being His honored servants. Every sinner should seize this good opportunity immediately before the Day of Judgment comes, when repentance and regret will no longer be accepted. Do not let this good opportunity pass by because those who do not heed it will be the ones who lose out. In another verse, Allah says:

Has the time not come for those who have believed that their hearts should become humbly submissive at the remembrance of Allah and what has come down of the truth? And let them not be like those who were given the Scripture before, and a long period passed over them, so their hearts hardened; and many of them are defiantly disobedient. (al-hadid/57: 16)

The golden opportunity that Allah has bestowed should be utilized as best as possible before the decisive moment arrives when the door of repentance has been tightly closed, namely when death has arrived or when the Day of Judgment has come. At that time, not a single disobedient person can escape from Allah's punishment, and no creature can defend or protect him from that torment. He should truly follow and obey all the teachings that Allah has explained in the Al-Qur'an al-Karim for the good and happiness of mankind in this world and the hereafter. No one should wait until tomorrow to repent because he does not know if he will live until tomorrow. Perhaps someone promises himself that he will repent tomorrow evening, but who knows, before evening comes he has already died, and that very precious opportunity is lost.

In this verse, Allah declares to those who have gone astray and are unwilling to seize the opportunity to repent that the fate that befalls them is unavoidable because Allah has sufficiently provided lessons and warnings. Allah has also given them the opportunity to repent and do good, but all of that was ignored and disregarded.

They only followed their desires and whims, becoming disobedient, arrogant, and conceited. They also belong to the group of disbelievers (kafir). All their hopes and requests are rejected, and Allah's justice prevails upon them: those who do good and are pious are admitted into Paradise, and those who do evil and are disobedient are admitted into Hell.
text.60:
In this verse, Allah explains to the Prophet Muhammad that later on the Day of Judgment, he will see the faces of the disbelievers turn pitch black because of the extreme fear of seeing and experiencing how terrible and devastating the chaos will be at that time. There will be nothing that can save them, as if they are surrounded by danger and disaster from all directions. Wherever they flee, they will always be confronted by terrifying things, so that nothing is on people's minds at that time except their own safety from the dangers of death. This is explained in Allah's words:

On that Day a man will flee from his brother, and from his mother and his father, and from his wife and his children. For every man, that Day, will be a matter adequate for him. ('Abasa/80: 34-37)

And His words:

Indeed, We fear from our Lord a Day that is harsh and distressful. (al-Insan/76: 10)

Besides not seeing anything that can help or prevent them from danger, they also know that they will be dragged into hell because of their disobedience and arrogance during their lives in the world. They did not want to believe and even always insulted and mocked those who believed, considering them a weak people who would follow the teachings of the messenger sent by Allah. If in the world a person's face turns pale when facing danger and may turn blue with fear, then on the Day of Judgment the face of the disbeliever will turn pitch black because of panic and extreme fear. That is the fate of those who will surely be dragged and thrown into the blazing fire of hell.

Hadith of the Prophet saw:

Narrated by 'Abdullah bin 'Umar that the Messenger of Allah saw said (about the fate of the arrogant disbelievers), "On the Day of Judgment, the arrogant will be gathered as if they were insignificant seeds. They will remain in a state of humiliation until they are dragged into Hell Jahannam." (Narrated by Ahmad and at-Tirmidzi)
text.61:
Then Allah explains the state of those who believe and are pious. On the Day of Judgment, they will be saved by Allah from the chaos and dangers that threaten on that day. With Allah's help and righteous deeds in the world, they will be able to overcome all difficulties and save themselves from all kinds of dangers, until they enter Paradise where all kinds of difficulties and sorrows end. Their faces will be radiant white because they feel joyful and happy, as mentioned in the verse:

On that Day, some faces will be bright, laughing, and rejoicing. ('Abasa/80: 38-39)
text.62:
In these verses, Allah affirms that He is the Creator of everything that exists, both in the heavens and on earth. He is the Creator of the entire universe; nothing can create besides Him. This is a truth that no one can deny. No one can claim to be the creator of the universe, because it is inconceivable that someone would have the power and authority to create this cosmos, and it is also inconceivable that this universe came into being by itself without a creator. Therefore, this universe must have been created by the All-Powerful and All-Knowing Being, that is Allah.

Allah is the One who manages everything that exists; His knowledge is vast, encompassing all of His creation. He controls the universe from the smallest to the largest. He controls all of that according to His knowledge, wisdom, and discretion. No creature interferes in that creation and control. This is what can be accepted by a sound mind and can be accepted by the human conscience.

Nevertheless, there are still many people who deny this truth and say that they are the ones in power, and they are God, as stated by Pharaoh, or put forward various theories about this universe to establish that the universe came into being by itself without anyone creating it. People like this are disbelievers who always deny the evidence of Allah's power both in the heavens and on earth and do not want to use the sound reasoning that Allah has bestowed upon them. These are the people whom Allah calls the most losers, both in this world and especially in the Hereafter.

Some commentators (mufasir) are of the opinion that what is meant by "Maqalid as-samawati wa al-ardh" (the keys of the heavens and the earth) here is its treasures. So, the keys to all the treasures stored in the heavens and on earth are in His hands. He is the One who maintains and guards them. He is the ruler who has the right to distribute them to whomever He wills. The Messenger of Allah said:

Narrated by Usman r.a. that when he asked the Messenger of Allah about Allah's saying "To Him belong the keys of the heavens and the earth," he replied, "O Usman, you are asking me something that no one has ever asked me before. 'Maqalid as-samawati wa al-ardh' is the utterance: There is no god but Allah, Allah is the Greatest, Glory be to Allah, all praise is due to Allah, I ask forgiveness of Allah, there is no god but He, the First, the Last, the Manifest, the Hidden, He gives life and causes death, while He remains alive and does not die, in His hand is all good, and He is powerful over all things." (Riwayat Abu Ya'la, Ibnu Abi hatim, dan Ibnu Mardawaih)

Whoever brings this utterance will receive the good that is in the heavens and on the earth.
