It is narrated by Ibn 'Abbas that the Quraysh people had offered the Prophet Muhammad abundant wealth, so that he would become the richest man in Mecca, and they would marry him to any woman he desired, but he had to stop denouncing their idols. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) responded to this offer, "Wait until a command comes from my Lord." Then Surah al-Kafirun/109 and verse 64 of Surah az-Zumar were revealed.

In this verse, Allah commands the Prophet Muhammad to say to the polytheists of Mecca who invited him to worship idols, that the invitation was a very misleading one. The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) said, "Is it possible for me to worship other than Allah, O ignorant people? I have witnessed the proofs of His Oneness, and He has guided me. I am convinced with all my heart and soul that He is Allah, the One and Almighty. Can this firm resolve of mine be bargained with unreasonable arguments?"

According to Ibn 'Abbas, the offer did not stop there; they even invited Muhammad to worship idols. Thus, they wanted to worship God alongside worshiping those idols.
text.65:
In this verse, Allah affirms to Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) that He has revealed to him and the previous prophets that if he were to associate partners with Allah, then all his good deeds of the past would be erased. This is a stern warning from Allah to mankind not to ever associate partners with Allah, because that act is shirk, and the sin of shirk is a sin that will not be forgiven by Allah. If a person dies in a state of shirk, the reward for all his good deeds will be erased, and he will be plunged into Hell, as mentioned in this verse:

"And whoever of you reverts from his religion and dies while he is a disbeliever - for those, their deeds have become worthless in this world and the Hereafter, and those are the companions of the Fire, they will abide therein eternally." (al-Baqarah/2: 217)

Allah gives a warning to Prophet Muhammad himself, even though he is the messenger He sent, His beloved messenger who would never associate partners with Him. Nevertheless, Allah also warns him not to even let it cross his mind to embrace a religion of shirk. All the more so, this warning should receive serious attention from other people. It is truly unbecoming for someone who knows how great Allah's blessings are upon him, upon all of mankind, to deny those blessings and violate the command of the Giver of Blessings by associating partners with Him, by seeking help from idols, graves, trees, and so on.

Allah then reinforces His command by issuing another command, which is that only Allah should be worshipped, only to Him should mankind offer all their acts of worship, and to Allah also should mankind raise their prayers and express gratitude, because He is the true Giver of Blessings, as every Muslim recites in prayer:

"Indeed, my prayer, my worship, my life and my death are for Allah, Lord of the worlds." (al-An'am/6: 162)
text.66:
In this verse, Allah affirms to Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, that He has revealed to him and the prophets before him that if he were to associate partners with Allah, then all his good deeds of the past would be erased. This is a stern warning from Allah to mankind not to ever associate partners with Allah, because that act is shirk, and the sin of shirk is a sin that will not be forgiven by Allah. If a person dies in a state of shirk, the reward for all his good deeds will be erased, and he will be plunged into Hell, as mentioned in this verse:

"And whoever of you reverts from his religion [to disbelief] and dies while he is a disbeliever - for those, their deeds have become worthless in this world and the Hereafter, and those are the companions of the Fire, they will abide therein eternally." (al-Baqarah/2: 217)

Allah gives a warning to Prophet Muhammad himself, even though he is the messenger He sent, His beloved messenger who would never associate partners with Him. Nevertheless, Allah also warns him not to even let it cross his mind to embrace a religion of shirk. All the more so for other people, this warning should receive serious attention. It is truly not fitting for a person who knows how great Allah's blessings are upon him, upon all of humanity, to deny those blessings and violate the command of the Giver of those blessings by associating partners with Him, by seeking help from idols, graves, trees, and so on.

Allah then reinforces His command by issuing another command, which is that only Allah should be worshipped, only to Him should mankind offer all their acts of worship, and to Allah also should mankind raise their prayers and express gratitude, because He is the true Giver of blessings, as every Muslim recites in prayer:

"Indeed, my prayer, my worship, my life and my death are for Allah, Lord of the worlds." (al-An'am/6: 162)
text.67:
In this verse, Allah rebukes the actions of the polytheists of Mecca for worshiping idols and statues, denying His greatness and power. Allah also reminds them of the immense blessings He has bestowed upon them. It is as if the ones in control and bestowing blessings are the powerless statues they made with their own hands. How low their way of thinking is, glorifying something that is insignificant and powerless. Allah further affirms that the earth in its entirety is in His grasp on the Day of Judgment, and the heavens will be rolled up in His right hand. If the heavens and the earth are all in His grasp, then who is greater, more magnificent, and more powerful than Allah? Are they glorifying those statues when the statues are only a small part of the heavens and the earth? Regarding this verse, Imam al-Bukhari narrated from Ibn Mas'ud a hadith:

One of the scholars came to the Messenger of Allah (saw) and said to him, "O Muhammad, indeed I found (in our book) that Allah the Almighty places the heavens on one of His fingers, the earth on another finger, the trees on another finger, water and soil on another finger, and other creatures on another finger, then He says, 'I am the king.'" The Messenger of Allah (saw) laughed upon hearing the scholar's words until his molars were visible as a sign of agreement. Then the Prophet (saw) recited this verse 67.

Regarding the depiction of the heavens and the earth in His grasp, it can perhaps be understood to mean that the universe is in His power. We do not know the true reality of the state of the earth being in Allah's grasp. It is one of the matters of the unseen (ghaib), which must be accepted as Allah has explained it. What must be fully believed is that Allah cannot be likened to anything. Allah's word:

There is nothing like unto Him, and He is the All-Hearing, the All-Seeing. (ash-Shura/42: 11)

Then Allah concludes this verse by stating that associating partners with Allah, especially with something trivial and powerless like those statues, is a misguided and misleading act. Glory be to Allah from all those understandings, and it is not befitting for His power and majesty to be associated with others.
text.68:
In this verse, Allah explains that there will be two trumpet blasts on the Day of Judgment. The first blast will cause all living things in the heavens and on earth to die. Due to the terrifying sound of the blast, all living beings will become paralyzed and helpless, eventually dying like someone struck by lightning or high-voltage electricity. There are creatures of Allah who will not die at that time because Allah does not will their death, but who they are is not mentioned in the Qur'an, nor in authentic hadith. Therefore, we leave the knowledge of this to Allah. Perhaps He did not mention His creatures who will not die for a reason or wisdom whose true nature we do not know. However, according to a narration from Abu Ya'la al-Maushuli, the creatures who will not die are the Angels Jibril, Mikail, and Izrail. After that, these creatures will also die one by one.

After the first blast, when almost all living creatures have died, the second trumpet blast will follow. With this second blast, all creatures who have died, both those who died before the first blast and those who died at the time of the blast, will come back to life. Each one will stand waiting for what will happen to them. There are several hadith regarding this trumpet blast, including:

1.  A hadith narrated by Abu Dawud from Abu Sa'id al-Khudri: The Messenger of Allah mentioned the one who will blow the trumpet and said, "On his right is Jibril and on his left is Mikail."

2.  A hadith narrated by Ibn Majah al-Bazzar and Ibn Mardawaih from Abu Sa'id al-Khudri: Indeed, in the hands of the two who will blow the trumpet are two horns that they will blow. They both always monitor the surrounding situation, and whenever they are commanded.

In addition, in the Qur'an, the trumpet blast is referred to as *az-Zajrah*, as mentioned in the verse:

"It will be only a single blast, and at once they will be observing!" (ash-Shaffat/37: 19)

And in the verse:

"It will be only a single blast, and at once they will be [back] on the surface." (an-Nazi'at/79: 13-14)

In other verses, it is also mentioned as " *dakwah* " (a call), as in the verse:

"And of His signs is that the heaven and earth stand by His command. Then when He calls you with [one] call from the earth, immediately you will come forth." (ar-Rum/30: 25)
text.69:
After all those events, the earth of the Gathering Place shone brightly, bathed in the light of God, because God's justice was established, and all good and bad deeds were weighed, placed before each person's record of deeds, as mentioned in the verse:

And We have fastened every man's deeds to his neck, and on the Day of Resurrection We shall bring forth for him a book which he will find wide open. (al-Isra'/17: 13)

And in the verse:

And the Book (of Deeds) will be placed (before you); and you will see the sinners fearful of that which is (recorded) therein. They will say: "Woe to us! What a Book is this! It leaves nothing small or great, but has recorded it with numbers!" And they will find all that they did placed before them. And your Lord wrongs no one. (al-Kahf/18: 49)

Also, the prophets are brought forth to be witnesses over the deeds of their people. This is also explained in another verse:

How then will it be, when We bring from each nation a witness and We bring you (O Muhammad) as a witness against these people? (an-Nisa'/4: 41)

Besides the prophets as witnesses, other witnesses are also brought forth, namely the angels who record all their deeds. This is mentioned in the verse:

And every soul will come with it a driver and a witness. (Qaf/50: 21)

Apart from the book of deeds and the trusted witnesses, there are also witnesses consisting of one's own body parts, such as feet and hands. All these body parts will recount what they have done, as mentioned in the verse:

On the Day when their tongues, their hands, and their feet will bear witness against them as to what they used to do. (an-Nur/24: 24)

One can imagine how magnificent the court of God will be at that time. A court that can decide every case and sentence people with the fairest of decisions, so that no one is harmed or wronged by it. The highest court, complete with trusted witnesses whose truth cannot be refuted, because each witness corroborates the testimony of the other witnesses. At that moment, the fate of each person is decided and determined based on the truth, and it is impossible for the decision to contradict justice or cause someone to be wronged or oppressed. This is found in the verse:

And We place the scales of justice for the Day of Resurrection, so no soul will be treated unjustly at all. And if there is (even) the weight of a mustard seed, We will bring it forth. And sufficient are We as accountant. (al-Anbiya'/21: 47)
text.70:
After passing through the scales that weigh with the utmost justice, only then will each person's deeds be rewarded perfectly, the good rewarded manifold and the evil with what is equivalent. No one will protest the decision and the reward. Rejoice are those who believe and do many good deeds, and wretched and regretful are the disbelievers who throughout their lives in the world were always arrogant and haughty and committed many sins and acts of disobedience.

Actually, there is no need for a very meticulous and careful procedure and witnesses that cannot be rejected, because all the deeds of Allah's servants are already in the vast knowledge of Allah, and He is absolutely powerful on that day. He can treat His servants according to His will without any proof of someone's wrongdoing, but Allah, the All-Wise, wants all the decisions He makes to be seen by His servants at that time, all based on evidence that can no longer be refuted.
text.71:
In this verse, Allah explains that the disbelievers who associate partners with Allah, such as idols and other objects of worship, are driven to Hell in a harsh manner. They are driven in groups, starting with the most misguided and rebellious group, followed by groups with lower levels of disobedience, and so on. Each group that arrives at Hell has its gates opened, and they are pushed forcefully, causing them to plunge into it. This is clearly depicted in the following verse:

Woe on that Day to the deniers, Who are engaged in idle talk. On the Day when they will be driven to the Fire of Hell with a [violent] driving. [It will be said], "This is the Fire which you used to deny." (ath-Thur/52: 11-14)

The gates of Hell are closed after everyone has entered, as mentioned in the verse:

Indeed, it [the Fire] will be closed down upon them In extended columns. (al-Humazah/104: 8-9)

They are rebuked, reproached, and humiliated by the angels who guard the keys of Hell, who say, "Did not messengers from among yourselves come to you, calling you to obey and be devoted to Allah, and not to associate partners with Him?" The messengers also recited to them the verses of Allah, which proved the truth of their message with strong and clear evidence that could not be refuted. Why did they reject the call with arrogance and pride? They cannot answer the question because they are facing the reality that they will enter Hell. They openly admit that they were at fault for denying the messengers of Allah, driven by their desires, fear of losing influence, position, and so on. Such an admission is found in the following verse:

Every time a company is thrown therein, its keepers ask them, "Did there not come to you a warner?" They will say, "Yes, a warner did come to us, but we denied and said, 'Allah has not sent down anything. You are not but in great error.'" (al-Mulk/67: 8-9)
text.72: With the admission of their errors, the angels commanded them to enter into Hell (Jahannam). They will abide therein forever, with no one able to escape even for a moment, because Hell is a fitting abode for the arrogant and haughty. Hell is the worst place, filled with torment and suffering.
text.73:
In this verse, it is explained that the believing and pious people are guided with full respect towards the Garden of Paradise, Jannatun Na'im. They find its doors wide open, and the gatekeepers are waiting there with respect and wisdom, saying to them, "Assalamu 'alaikum." This is a welcome greeting for them, and a prayer to Allah that they may remain happy with the grace and blessings prepared for them in this Paradise. Then they are respectfully invited to enter Paradise immediately, and it is said to them, "You will abide therein forever."

The believers come in groups. The first group consists of those who are closest to Allah and have the highest rank in His sight, according to their faith, piety, and good deeds in the world. The second group consists of those who are of a lower rank than the first group. And so on, until all Muslims enter it. The gates of Paradise are open to them, as also mentioned in another verse:

This is an honor (for them). And indeed, for the righteous is a good place of return, (namely) the Gardens of 'Adn, whose doors are open to them. (Shad/38: 49-50)

In Paradise, they obtain all kinds of pleasures and delights that have never been imagined by anyone in this world. Such blessings and grace can be achieved through various kinds of deeds and worship performed by humans during their lifetime in the world.

It is explained by a hadith narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Umar bin Khaththab that the Messenger of Allah once said:

Whoever among you performs ablution perfectly, then says, "I bear witness that there is no god but Allah, and that Muhammad is His servant and Messenger," the eight gates of Paradise will be opened for him, and he will be allowed to enter from whichever gate he pleases. (Narrated by Muslim and others)

It is also narrated from Abu Hurairah that the Messenger of Allah (saw) once said:

The first group to enter Paradise will have faces like the full moon (on the fourteenth night). The next group will have faces as bright as the brightest star in the sky (the morning star). (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

Al-Bukhari and Muslim also narrated from Sahal bin Sa'ad that the Messenger of Allah said:

In Paradise, there are eight gates, one of which is called ar-Rayyan. This gate is only entered by those who fast.
text.74:
The believers, who are very happy and joyful seeing the blessings and pleasures they will enjoy in Paradise, say, "All praise is due to Allah who has fulfilled His promise to us, as conveyed by His Messenger and the prayer we always offer." Allah says:

Allah has promised the believing men and believing women gardens beneath which rivers flow, wherein they abide eternally, and good residences in gardens of perpetual residence; but the greatest of all is Allah's good pleasure. That is the supreme success. (at-Taubah/9: 72)

And Allah says:

Our Lord, give us what You have promised us through Your messengers and do not disgrace us on the Day of Resurrection. Indeed, You do not fail in [Your] promise. (ali 'Imran/3: 194)

The inhabitants of Paradise continue their words of praise and gratitude, "All praise is due to Allah who has made us heirs to this sign of Paradise so that we may reside in it, wherever we please and enjoy the various kinds of blessings He has provided in it." Among the pleasures of Paradise are as explained in the following words of Allah:

And close above them are its shades, and its [fruit] to be picked will be made easy. And there will be circulated among them vessels of silver and cups of crystal. (al-Insan/76: 14-15)

And they will be given to drink a cup [of wine] whose mixture is of ginger. From a spring within Paradise called Salsabil. (al-Insan/76: 17-18)

And there will circulate among them young boys made eternal. When you see them, you would think them [as beautiful] scattered pearls. And when you look there [in Paradise], you will see pleasure and great dominion. (al-Insan/76: 19-20)

(75) In this verse, Allah explains to the Prophet Muhammad what the atmosphere will be like in the Hereafter and the beautiful and amazing scenery where the angels surround the 'Arasy, glorifying Allah, ready to carry out the commands that will be revealed to them. The hum of their glorification is heard around the 'Arasy. Among them are those who are tasked with carrying the 'Arasy as mentioned in the verse:

And the angels are at its edges. And there will bear the Throne of your Lord above them, on that Day, eight [of them]. (al-haqqah/69: 17)

They stand in orderly rows as explained in the verse:

On the Day the Spirit and the angels will stand in rows, they will not speak except for one whom the Most Merciful permits, and he will speak what is correct. (an-Naba'/78: 38)

On that day, Allah will judge His servants with justice and truth. The words of glorification are heard simultaneously, "All praise is due to Allah, Lord of the worlds." The Lord who created the heavens and the earth, who created mankind to be His vicegerent on earth, giving him guidance and direction. He is the One who has prepared the punishment and torment of Hell for those who disobey Him, and promises blessings and favors to those who carry out His commands with obedience and submission. He is also the One who causes all His creatures to die on the Day of Resurrection and brings them back to life to receive the reward for their deeds, then holds a trial to account for all the deeds of His servants with justice, truth, and wisdom, then gives recompense to all His creatures. The disobedient are cast into Hell and the believers and the righteous are admitted into Paradise according to His promise. All praise is due to Allah for all His actions, His justice, and His mercy.
text.75:
In this verse, Allah explains to Prophet Muhammad the atmosphere in the afterlife, as well as the beautiful and amazing scenes where angels surround the 'Arash, glorifying and praising Allah, ready to carry out the commands that will be revealed to them. The hum of their glorification echoes around the 'Arash. Among them are those tasked with carrying the 'Arash, as mentioned in the verse:

And the angels will be on its sides, and eight will bear the Throne of your Lord above them on that Day. (al-Haqqah/69: 17)

They stand in orderly rows, as explained in the verse:

On the Day the Spirit and the angels will stand in rows, they will not speak except for one whom the Most Compassionate has permitted, and he will say what is correct. (an-Naba'/78: 38)

On that day, Allah will give His judgment to His servants with justice and truth. The utterance of glorification will be heard simultaneously, "All praise is due to Allah, Lord of the worlds." The Lord who created the heavens and the earth, who created mankind to be His vicegerent on earth, giving them guidance and direction. He is the One who has prepared punishment and torment in Hell for those who disobey Him, and promises blessings and favors to those who carry out His commands with obedience and devotion. He is also the One who causes all His creatures to die on the Day of Judgment and resurrects them to receive the recompense for their deeds, then holds a trial to account for all the deeds of His servants with justice, truth, and wisdom, and then gives recompense to all His creatures. The disobedient are cast into Hell, and the believers and the righteous are admitted into Paradise according to His promise. All praise is offered to Allah for all His actions, His justice, and His mercy.
